data.title: Object literal may only specify known properties, and 'indentSize' does not exist in type 'FormatCodeOptions'.
data.body:
- VSCode Version: latest

Trying to do a monaco build I get this error: 

```
/Users/syedb/REPOS/monaco/vscode/build/monaco/api.ts:220 Type '{ indentSize: number; tabSize: number; newLineCharacter: string; convertTabsToSpaces: boolean; in...' is not assignable to type 'FormatCodeOptions'.
  Object literal may only specify known properties, and 'indentSize' does not exist in type 'FormatCodeOptions'.
```

Think the case is changed in typescript :rose:

data.title: Text is not saved when file is renamed
data.body:
- VSCode Version: Code 1.8.1 (ee428b0eead68bf0fb99ab5fdc4439be227b6281, 2016-12-19T14:42:49.304Z)
- OS Version: Darwin x64 16.3.0
- Extensions:

|Extension|Author|Version|
|---|---|---|
|aurelia|AureliaEffect|0.2.0|
|vscode-pandoc|DougFinke|0.0.8|
|Aurelia|behzad88|1.2.1|
|path-intellisense|christian-kohler|1.2.0|
|tslint|eg2|0.7.1|
|Go|lukehoban|0.6.52|
|debugger-for-chrome|msjsdiag|2.4.2|
|todotasks|sandy081|0.4.0|
|code-spell-checker|streetsidesoftware|0.13.3|

---

Steps to Reproduce:

1. open a new window and type in some text.
2. save file eg as "test" (no extension).
3. add some more text.
4. click on file in the Explorer window and change file name to eg "test.md"

Expected:
- text entered in step 3 is saved OR a prompted to save changes.

what happened:
- text entered in step 3 is not saved without prompt or warning.

data.title: Persisting "disable by workspace" settings in source control

milestone.title: Backlog
milestone.description: Work not yet planned for a specific release.

data.body:
- VSCode Version: 1.8.1

Can this setting be saved in the workspace setting.json so I don't need to ask every developer to disable the extension (if installed)?

In my company, our main product is stored in perforce so I use the perforce extension.
However, there are many small projects stored in git (bitbucket).

Optimally, I would like to "enable by workspace" and "disable by default", but if that is not available, then storing the setting would be the second best option.

Or maybe I should just suggest that feature instead? ðŸŒ·

data.title: Add New Context For When an Html Preview Is Focused
data.body: Adds a new context called `htmlPreviewFocus` that is active when an HtmlPreview editor is focused. This will be required to support features such as #2187: adding search to the webview, which I imagine being implemented similarly to `StartSearchDefaultSettingsCommand`

data.title: chore(performance test): Add performance test criteria
data.body:
- VSCode Version: 1.8.1

I love vscode and using it every day.
It works better for me compare to all other editors and it is the speediest of the bunch.

As vscode continues to grow, it may be a good time to start investing in adding some performance criteria so that we can ensure the IDE performance does not degrade as more features are added.

Criteria such as:

- without extensions
  - Starts within 3 seconds
  - Command Palette shows within 100 ms
 
I'm not performance experts and will leave it at your good hands in defining more criteria.

If such criteria already exist, that's great. ðŸŒ·

data.title: Prototype Using Commit Characters for JS and TS Completions
data.body:
Part of #7326

Adds a prototype for using specific characters to complete TS/JS completion items automatically.

Work to do:

- [ ] Add setting to disable this (and only apply in TS files perhaps to match existing behavior)
- [ ] Get this to play nicely with `typescript.useCodeSnippetsOnMethodSuggest` (not a regression actually)
- [x] Improve completions for paths and module names

data.title: Feature Request: Workspace-specific keybindings.json
data.body:
I am preparing to lead a workshop where I will be using VSCode as the suggested code editor. I've been able to bundle some useful settings, extensions and tasks directly for the class via the .vscode directory. Unfortunately, there is no way to bundle suggested keybindings for my project in the same way.

Technically, it seems relatively straightforward: the json format is already specified and keybindingResolver.ts is already wired up to take in the fixed native mappings and override them with the user-specific keybindings. This could either be extended to take two sets of overrides, or the workspace-specific ones could be concatenated to the user-specific override list.

Rather, I think the biggest problem is a matter of determining what .vscode/keybindings.json should do. Personally, I'd like to just use any keybindings found in that file first, then defer to user settings, then defer to native (just like the other .vscode config files), but before I consider working on a PR, I'd like to get some more opinions on what people think about this idea.

data.title: Expose detected-link color to themes
data.body: Extracted from discussion at #18357

data.title: Allow terminals to be reused
data.body:
From @dbaeumer:

> Reuse of a terminal. Not necessarily the terminal process more the terminal pane. If the user executes a task and the task finishes and runs the task again it would be cool if the output of the task could show up in the same terminal. Constantly pressing a key to close and old terminal might not be very intuitive.

data.title: Terminal should throw an event when a terminal has completed (and is waiting to close)
data.body:
From @dbaeumer:

> an event when a task executed in a terminal has finished (e.g. the terminal process existed)

data.title: Question - Can QuickOpen go to the open file in a different editor group?
data.body:
- VSCode Version: 1.8.1
- OS Version: Windows 7

Is this currently a setting? 
If I have 2 editor groups, Group A has index.html, Group B does not have index.html. I'm focused in Group B and I use QuickOpen (ctrl+p) to open index.html, can I make it focus the opened index.html in Group A?

data.title: How should extensions programmatically set the languageId or files.associations?
data.body:
I'm not sure if this is the correct place to ask this...

Our C++ extension knows that certain files located via #include <string> should have a languageId = "cpp" or "c", so we want to be able to set that for the files (opened via Go To Definition) or automatically add it to the files.associations setting. What method do you guys recommend? Making edits to settings.json is problematic because it is non-standard JSON with comments and I don't know a parser that allows roundtrip insertions into it that preserve the comments. Having access to some internal parser like ConfigurationEditingService.writeConfiguration might work but that doesn't seem to be available via the public extension APIs.

data.title: source maps interpretation inconsistent
data.body:
- VSCode Version: `Version 1.8.1 (1.8.1)`
- OS Version: `osx 10.11.6`

# problem statement

- source maps are only periodically honored, based on compiled content.

# discussion

- i confess, this _may_ be an issue with `babel`s sourceMap output, but i'm still debugging that.  i figured i'd post this in advanced in case there is existing visibility or ideas people might have.

# example

1. observe a compile->test->debug session, watch sourceMaps **not** be honored
1. add a `debugger` statement. observe another compile->test->debug session, watch sourceMaps **be** honored

![babel-sourcemaps-not-honored mov](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/1003261/21821896/12939166-d72a-11e6-94c9-bee39f451510.gif)

Steps to Reproduce:

1. see https://github.com/cdaringe/babel-vscode-source-map-woes

data.title: editor.quickSuggestions setting for completion providers
data.body:
I have set `editor.quickSuggestions` to `false` and like to bring the suggestions up manually when I need them. Recently I encountered an issue with an extension (ChristianKohler/PathIntellisense#52) where the autocompletion popup is shown upon hitting `/`.

Investigating the API in more detail it seems that the registered *trigger characters* are used to trigger the extension in a generic fashion, independent of the extension's specific function. So while the corresponding *trigger characters* should still be registered, in the case of a `CompletionItemProvider` such a character should only trigger the extension if `editor.quickSuggestions` is set to `true`.

What do you think about this?

data.title: Sometimes initial CharMeasure.measure() does not give accurate measurements
Terminal scroll bar does not appear (or work) sometimes
data.body:
This happened after one of the recent xterm.js uplevels.

Reasonably reliable repro steps:

1. Open terminal
2. Create a new instance (2+)
3. Run `ll`

Resizing the window will refresh the scroll bar and it will work fine after that.

data.title: Tasks::problemMatcher should highlight problems in output log and make files clickable
data.body:
I tried everything, but I'm not able to make vs-code to highlight problems in output log and make that problems clickable (click on file that will bring me to the file/line/column of the problem).

I know I can press Ctrl+Shift+M and see all problems, but that's kinda something I don't want to do if I already see the output log. I want to see something Visual Studio does when compiling the project, for example...

data.title: Why does editor.action.marker.next/prev remove focus from the editor?
data.body:
- VSCode Version: Code - Insiders 1.9.0-insider (12af9ea6effefeaeecde2107c960ae5222703864, 2017-01-09T07:18:17.300Z)
- OS Version: Linux x64 4.8.0-30-generic
- Extensions:

|Extension|Author|Version|
|---|---|---|
|EditorConfig|EditorConfig|0.3.4|
|lorem-ipsum|Tyriar|1.0.0|
|sort-lines|Tyriar|1.1.0|
|theme-glacier|Tyriar|0.0.10|
|vscode-svgviewer|cssho|1.3.0|
|vscode-eslint|dbaeumer|1.2.2|
|python|donjayamanne|0.5.5|
|tslint|eg2|0.8.1|
|git-project-manager|felipecaputo|1.0.0|
|Theme-Wombat|gerane|0.0.2|
|md-navigate|jrieken|0.0.1|
|vscode-scss|mrmlnc|0.6.0|
|typescript-javascript-grammar|ms-vscode|0.0.15|
|seti-icons|qinjia|0.1.3|
|sass-indented|robinbentley|1.3.0|
|dark-plus-material|vangware|0.1.4|

---

I _really_ want to get used to using F8/shift+F8 to navigate to errors on the page but it makes it difficult the way it messes with the editor's focus.

Steps to Reproduce:

1. Open a file with errors
2. Press F8, notice that focus is on the inline problem view itself, not the editor. This means in order to fix the error I need to either focus the editor (ctrl+<num>) or close the problem view (esc), the latter of which hides the error.

![image](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/2193314/21817716/f1bbba14-d719-11e6-9059-03e06d39142b.png)

This is the state that I want it in when I press F8, where esc will dismiss the problem view and F8 will go to the next problem, not focus the opened problem view:

![image](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/2193314/21817761/24c493cc-d71a-11e6-9a82-32d70f37706b.png)
